Key Arguments: The submission expresses non-consent to the proposed legislation, arguing that it is a tool for censorship and oppression.
It claims that politicians and mainstream media are principal sources of misinformation and disinformation.
The submission argues that the legislation should apply equally to all media and public statements by politicians, otherwise it is deemed fascist.
It suggests that censorship is a sign of a weak government that fears free speech.
The submission implies that the bill will lead to an internet dominated by state-sponsored propaganda.
It proposes financial penalties for any enforcement of the bill that affects the submitter's access to information or causes a 'chilling effect'.
Main Themes: Financial liability and personal responsibility of lawmakers
Notable Quotes: The proposed Bill is an instrument for censorship and oppression, nothing less.
A government employing censorship is weak; questions its own authority; fears the might of people; and assumes a questionable ethical foundation.
The outcome of this Bill in practical terms is an internet existing exclusively of state-sponsored propaganda.
